a.style: background:#00ae9c; border-radius:0px 0px 0px 0px; font-weight:normal; font-family:Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; bottom:-2px; right: 150px; padding:4px 10px 4px 10px; font-size:24px; color:#fff;text-align:center; cursor:pointer;border:none;text-decoration: none;box-shadow: 0 0 8px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5); z-index:999999

a.span: Fall Call to Adventure/Spring into the Woods

div.font:
Â COVID 19 represents a unique challenge, what is easy for us at Pioneer Springs is the priority of safety, and it is with that singular focus in mind that we are preparing a temporary shift to a remote instructional model. On Tuesday March 17th our students began virtual learning. Activities, field trips and events for this time will be cancelled or postponed. We look forward to being back together again, until then we encourage everyone to enjoy some time outdoors and keep washing those hands!
Click here for some nature based virtualÂ learning ideas/

strong.font:
Welcome to Pioneer Springs Community School,
the region's only nature-based free public charter school.
WhereÂ learning comes naturally.

em.font:
âStudents are empowered to live their learning in an authentic environment connecting them to nature Â and community.
We believe in educating the whole child, academically, physically, socially and emotionally.

div.em:
âPioneer Springs Community School is a dynamic school that has tremendous support from all stakeholders.
Deeply ingrained in the culture and operation of the institution is a nurturing environment that gives students equitable
opportunities to access resources that promote collaboration and individualized learning.â

span.style: display: block; clear: both; height: 0px; overflow: hidden;

em.font:
"Must we always teach our children with books? Let them look at the mountains and the stars up above. Let them look at the beauty of the waters and the trees and flowers on earth. They will then begin to think, and to think is the beginning of a real education."
ââ David Polis

span.font: Ground was broken on our new facilities expansion. Dubbed âThe Hive,â the project consists of new middle and high school facilities totaling over 18,000 square feet. Configured in a honeycomb-like array, these individual classroom buildings of approximately 750 square feet each are integrated seamlessly into the natural landscape to create a connected learning community for 6th-12th grades.

The Hiveâs innovative design represents the schoolâs commitment to sustainable land development. Characterized by elevated decking connecting the individual structures, this design provides open-air spaces for scholars to work independently and in teams, along with assembly areas for educational and community gatherings. In addition, this green building solution safeguards the natural integrity of the schoolâs pond by mitigating the stormwater run-off resulting from traditional impervious surfaces and hardscapes.Â Phase One,Â the middle school construction, will begin next week and is proposed to be completed by August 2020, providing English, Math, Science, and Humanities classrooms for the upcoming school year.
